<div id="root">
	<div><!-- duplicate React-root div for styling -->
	<div class="content">
		<article class="article-container article--post ">
			<header class="article__header ">
	<div class="article__title-wrapper">
						<h1 class="article__title">Mastodon’s microblogging app saw a record number of downloads after Musk’s Twitter takeover</h1>
		</div>

			<div class="article__byline-wrapper">
			
<div class="article__byline">
			<a href="https://techcrunch.com/author/sarah-perez/">
			Sarah Perez		</a>
		<span class="article__byline__meta">
							<a href="https://twitter.com/sarahintampa">@sarahintampa</a>
				<span class="text--green"> / </span>
						7 days		</span>
	</div>
		</div>
	
			<div class="article__featured-image-wrapper breakout">
			<img src="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Mastodon-Elephant-Friend.jpg?w=711" class="article__featured-image" />
		</div>
	</header>

			<div class="article-content">
				<p id="speakable-summary">There are signs of a small but growing Twitter exodus underway following Elon Musk’s <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2022/10/27/elon-musk-bought-twitter/">closure of the deal</a> to buy the social media platform last Thursday. While many Twitter users are taking a wait-and-see approach and may not have fully deleted their accounts at this time, a sizable number of people are currently checking out Twitter alternatives. One of those alternatives is <a href="https://joinmastodon.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Mastodon</a>, a decentralized social network that gained more than 70,000 new sign-ups on Friday, the day after the Musk Twitter takeover completed. And this weekend, the official Mastodon mobile app saw a record number of downloads as more people fleeing Twitter began to seek out a new online home.</p>
<p><a href="https://joinmastodon.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Mastodon</a>, to be clear, is not a new platform. The free and open source microblogging service <a href="https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/releases/tag/v0.1.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener">debuted in March 2016</a>, offering a different approach to online social networking. Similar to Twitter, you can follow other users and create posts that can be liked and retweeted (or “tooted,” in Mastodon lingo), use hashtags, share media and more. But unlike Twitter, Mastodon is a distributed social network where users sign up on individual servers, or nodes, each with its own theme, rules, language and moderation policy. For instance, the most popular server currently is <a href="https://mastodon.social" target="_blank" rel="noopener">mastodon.social</a>, <a href="https://instances.social/mastodon.social" target="_blank" rel="noopener">touting</a> 817,219 users. A Japanese server <a href="https://pawoo.net/about" target="_blank" rel="noopener">pawoo.net</a> is just behind that with some <a href="https://instances.social/pawoo.net" target="_blank" rel="noopener">766,399 users</a>.</p>
<p>Users can generally view content and interact with people on other servers, with the exception of any servers in the “<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fediverse" target="_blank" rel="noopener">fediverse</a>” — the group of interconnected, or federated, servers — that their own server admin has banned.</p>
<p>Mastodon works on the web or mobile, including through native mobile apps. In addition to the main Mastodon mobile client, there’s a long list of third-party clients to choose from, too, with names like Tootle, Metatext, Mast, tooot, Toot!, Mastoot, Twidere X, Mercury for Mastodon, Tootoise, Tootter for Mastodon, Stella and more.</p>
<p>There were already signs last week that Mastodon was benefiting from the chaos and concern that’s accompanied the chaotic change in Twitter’s ownership.</p>
<div class="embed breakout">
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-width="550" data-dnt="true">
<p lang="en" dir="ltr">Looks like <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/Mastodon?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#Mastodon</a> is trending on Twitter as more and more people are announcing their new profiles. Welcome to the better social media that does not belong to a single company and cannot be sold, welcome to the fediverse! <a href="https://t.co/75pugCA0si">pic.twitter.com/75pugCA0si</a></p>
<p>— Mastodon (@joinmastodon) <a href="https://twitter.com/joinmastodon/status/1585651032998150146?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">October 27, 2022</a></p></blockquote><div class="piano-inline-promo"></div>
<p></div>
<p>On Friday, <a href="https://twitter.com/joinmastodon/status/1585651032998150146" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the hashtag #mastodon began trending</a> and many people were tweeting #TwitterMigration as they prepared to make the shift to the open source service. Even in advance of the Twitter sale, some were checking out Mastodon, noted <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/gargron/?originalSubdomain=de" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Eugen Rochko, Mastodon’s founder</a> and lead developer. He said that 18,000 people signed up for Mastodon accounts in the week leading up to the Twitter sale (October 20 to October 27), <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/twitter-users-flock-to-other-platforms-as-the-elon-musk-era-begins/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Wired</a> reported at the time.</p>
<p>On Friday, Mastodon <a href="https://twitter.com/joinmastodon/status/1586525904997863427" target="_blank" rel="noopener">shared</a> that number had increased by quite a bit: More than 70,000 people signed up for a Mastodon account on that day alone (October 28). (<a href="https://mastodon.social/@Gargron/109254422325596095" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Rochko later noted</a> the figure was actually 70,849, up from<a href="https://mastodon.social/@Gargron/109247989447397169" target="_blank" rel="noopener"> 10,801</a> the day prior.)</p>
<p>This influx of new users also helped boost the Mastodon mobile app. As of Friday afternoon, the app had jumped to No. 38 in the Social Networking category on the U.S. App Store, data from app intelligence firm <a href="http://www.sensortower.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sensor Tower</a> indicated. This was the app’s highest rank since April 27, 2022 when it had ranked No. 37 — shortly after <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2022/04/14/elon-musk-offers-to-buy-twitter-for-43-billion/">Musk made his initial offer to buy Twitter</a>, prompting the first Twitter exodus. The highest rank the app had ever seen then was No. 31 on April 26, 2022.</p>
<p>That’s since changed, Sensor Tower tells us. The app has now moved up to No. 21 in the Social Networking category on the U.S. App Store, topping its earlier high.</p>
<p>It also saw the most installs ever in a single day on Saturday, October 29, with 34,000 new downloads across both iOS and Android that day. And, over the past three days (October 28-30) the app has seen around 91,000 new installs, Sensor Tower says. That’s up 658% when compared with the 12,000 installs from the prior three days (October 25-27). It’s also a sizable chunk of the lifetime installs the app has seen to date, which now total 489,000 across iOS and Android. Germany is Mastodon’s largest market with 37% of installs, followed by the U.S. with 19% and Japan with 7%.</p>
<p>However, despite breaking records, Mastodon’s mobile app hasn’t yet broken into the Top Overall iPhone apps on the U.S. App Store. That could be because Mastodon has such a long tail of third-party clients that some app downloads from new users are being siphoned away from the main app and directed elsewhere. <span style="font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;">For example, the Mastodon app MetaText jumped up 14 positions in its ranking in the Social Networking category, while Mercury moved up three ranks. Neither are all that sizable, though, with Social Networking category ranks of 469 and 1,295, respectively. </span></p>
<p>There’s no doubt this rapid growth in Mastodon app downloads is directly tied to the Musk Twitter takeover. However, Mastodon’s growth isn’t the only sign that some Twitter users are abandoning the platform.</p>
<p>Twitter developer partner <a href="https://tweepsmap.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Tweepsmap</a>, a Twitter analytics provider, saw a slightly higher than usual drop in the number of “unfollows” on the platform among a sample size of 400,000 Twitter users on Friday, October 28 — or about 30% higher than the usual Friday average. This could signal a somewhat higher number of users were deactivating their accounts than is usual, leading to them “unfollowing” other users as a result.</p>
<p>The only other pattern Tweepsmap could detect was that liberal-leaning accounts had higher than usual losses, with a follower drop of < 0.2% — a decline that’s not significant in the grand scheme of things, but also not entirely negligible, either, the company told us. That would likely correlate with the types of Twitter users who are looking to exit a Musk-led platform, but it’s still small enough of an exit to not really hurt Twitter at present.</p>
<p>In the meantime, <a href="https://mastodon.social/@Gargron/109262705755044079" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Rochko posted</a> that he’s purchased more powerful hardware to upgrade Mastodon’s database server given the influx of users has led to processing delays, and noted he’s been <a href="https://mastodon.social/@Gargron/109260523394620554" target="_blank" rel="noopener">working 12- to 14-hour days</a> in light of the recent growth. Unlike Twitter, Mastodon doesn’t make billions from advertising — it’s <a href="https://mastodon.social/@Gargron/109256990373721673">supported</a> by individuals and organizations, often from their own pocket, and by user donations. (So if you’re among those fleeing Twitter, <a href="https://www.patreon.com/mastodon" target="_blank" rel="noopener">consider stepping up</a>.)</p>
<p>The interest in Mastodon has now led to the most popular server, <a href="https://mastodon.social/home">mastodon.social</a>, experiencing outages. The organization informed us it has gained 123,562 new users as of October 27, 2022 and now has 528,607 active users on the network as of October 31, 2022.</p>
<p><em>Update, 11/1/2022, 3:20 PM ET to add information about the outage and new metrics from Mastodon. </em></p>

subscribers as the social network attempts to steer clear of possible impact to Tuesday’s midterm elections.<\/p>\n<p>The Elon Musk-owned social media company had planned to roll out the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/01\/elon-musk-says-twitter-blue-will-cost-8-month-with-regional-pricing\/\">revamped version of its subscription<\/a> service, Twitter Blue, on Monday. The firm started <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/05\/twitter-begins-rolling-out-7-99-twitter-blue-plan-with-verification-fewer-ads\/\">testing the new features on Saturday<\/a>, according to an app update note.<\/p>\n<p>Twitter did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<\/p>\n<p>The reported move to delay the rollout of verification badges comes just days before the U.S. midterm elections, with polls closing on November 8. <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2022\/11\/06\/technology\/twitter-verification-check-marks.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The New York Times<\/a> reports that the move was aimed at limiting the potential fallout of verified users impersonating political or other government figures, such as President Biden, or news outlets claiming href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/04\/12\/bidens-cybersecurity-dream-team-takes-shape\/\">tasked with overseeing election security<\/a> and protecting voting infrastructure, said <a href=\"https:\/\/www.cbsnews.com\/news\/midterms-cisa-jen-easterly-election-infrastructure-face-the-nation\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">last week<\/a> that the agency had found “no information credible or specific about efforts to disrupt or compromise,\u201d but warned of the ongoing risks posed by disinformation campaigns sown by foreign actors aimed at undermining confidence in the elections system.<\/p>\n<p>Security experts like Chris Krebs, the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/11\/17\/trump-fires-us-cybersecurity-official-chris-krebs-for-debunking-false-election-claims\/\">former CISA director<\/a> who was fired by President Trump for refuting false claims of election fraud, <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/C_C_Krebs\/status\/1589022843706408963\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">warned<\/a> that Twitter’s new verification rules would be a “major risk” ahead of the midterm elections.<\/p>\n<p>At the time of writing, several verified users were impersonating Elon Musk, Twitter’s new owner, despite the risk of having their accounts suspended for impersonation.<\/p>\n<p>The revamped Twitter Blue, which will cost $7.99 a month in the U.S., includes a range of new features including the coveted blue check mark to anyone who subscribes as well as cuts down the number of ads served to them on the platform.<\/p>\n<p>Musk is betting on turning the subscription service into a major revenue source for Twitter, which he <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/27\/elon-musk-bought-twitter\/\">acquired last month for $44 billion<\/a>. whatsapp-launches-communities\/","title":{"rendered":"This Week in Apps: Twitter chaos, Mastodon grows and WhatsApp launches Communities"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Welcome back to This Week in Apps, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/this-week-in-apps\/\">the weekly TechCrunch series<\/a> that recaps the latest in mobile OS news, mobile applications and the overall app economy.<\/p>\n<p>Global <a href=\"https:\/\/sensortower.com\/blog\/app-revenue-and-downloads-1h-2022\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">app spending reached $65 billion<\/a> in the first half of 2022, up only slightly from the $64.4 billion during the same period in 2021, as hypergrowth fueled by the pandemic has decreased. But overall, the app economy is continuing to grow, having produced <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/12\/07\/app-stores-to-see-record-consumer-spend-of-133-billion-in-2021-143-6-billion-new-app-installs\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">a record<\/a> number of downloads and consumer spending across both the iOS and Google Play stores combined in 2021, according to the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/12\/07\/app-stores-to-see-record-consumer-spend-of-133-billion-in-2021-143-6-billion-new-app-installs\/\">latest<\/a> year-end <a href=\"https:\/\/www.appannie.com\/en\/insights\/market-data\/2021-end-year-mobile-apps-recap\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reports<\/a>. Global spending across iOS and Google Play last year was $133 billion, and consumers downloaded 143.6 billion apps.<\/p>\n<p>This Week in Apps offers a way to keep up with this fast-moving industry in one place, with the latest from the world of apps, including news, updates, startup fundings, mergers and acquisitions, and much more.<\/p>\n<p><em><strong>Do you want This Week in Apps in your inbox every Saturday? Sign up here: <a href=\"http:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\">techcrunch.com\/newsletters<\/a><\/strong><\/em><\/p>\n<h1>Top Stories<\/h1>\n<h3>Twitter is dying, long live Twitter?<\/h3>\n<p>Has it really only been a week since <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/elon-buys-twitter\/\">Elon Musk bought Twitter<\/a>? It seems like a lifetime.<\/p>\n<p>The Tesla and SpaceX exec has wasted no time making the bird app his own, beginning with the almost immediate layoffs of the Twitter executive team, including CEO Parag Agrawal, CFO Ned Segal, General Counsel Sean Edgett and Head of Legal Policy, Trust and Safety Vijaya Gadde, before moving on to cut upper management, and then the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/03\/twitter-layoffs-elon-musk\/\">widespread layoffs of staff.<\/a> (Which he’s <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/04\/twitter-faces-a-class-action-lawsuit-over-mass-employee-layoffs-with-proper-legal-notice\/\">now being sued over,<\/a> in fact, as the required 60 days legal notice wasn’t given.) Twitter is expected to cut 50% of its staff, or some 3,700 jobs.<\/p>\n<p>The roles being cut <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/04\/elon-musk-twitter-layoffs\/\">span areas large and small<\/a>, from the mission-critical <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/jackiedavalos1\/status\/1587260948938719232\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">moderation,<\/a>\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/jackiedavalos1\/status\/1587260948938719232\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">trust & safety<\/a>, <a href=\"https:\/\/appleinsider.com\/articles\/22\/11\/04\/twitter-lays-off-staff-including-whole-ethics-team-temporarily-closes-offices?utm_medium=rss\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ethical AI<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/AndrewHaigh\/status\/1588468986596859904\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">curation<\/a> teams — just ahead of a major election, worryingly — as well as those working on more experimental features, like <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/HiCommunities\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Communities<\/a>, and in all sorts of business and tech areas like marketing, sales, policy, research, partnerships, accessibility, data science, machine learning, social good, communications and more, including core engineering. Twitter’s Developer Platform lead is out and the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/02\/twitter-cancels-its-chirp-conference-for-developers-amid-management-transition\/\">developer conference Chirp was also canceled<\/a>.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"0RUFZwg8lj\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/04\/elon-musk-twitter-layoffs\/\">Elon Musk just axed key Twitter teams like human rights, accessibility, AI ethics and curation<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Elon Musk just axed key Twitter teams like human rights, accessibility, AI ethics and curation” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/04\/elon-musk-twitter-layoffs\/embed\/#?secret=ngyCdAbOVx#?secret=0RUFZwg8lj\" data-secret=\"0RUFZwg8lj\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<div class=\"msg-s-event-listitem msg-s-event-listitem--last-in-group msg-s-event-listitem--other \" data-event-urn=\"urn:li:fs_event:(2-MDg3ZjQxMGEtMGMyZi00M2QxLTgzMzEtZDkxZWFiMmJjNGZlXzAxMA==,2-MTY2NzU5MjM2ODE5M2IxMjYwOC0wMDMmMDg3ZjQxMGEtMGMyZi00M2QxLTgzMzEtZDkxZWFiMmJjNGZlXzAxMA==)\">\n<div class=\"msg-s-event-listitem__message-bubble msg-s-event-listitem__message-bubble--msg-fwd-enabled\" tabindex=\"0\" data-artdeco-is-focused=\"true\">Employees <a style=\"background-color: #ffffff; font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\" href=\"https:\/\/www.theverge.com\/2022\/11\/4\/23439790\/elon-musk-twitter-layoffs-trust-and-safety-teams-severance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">are already warning<\/a><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\"> that such significant cuts combined with cost-cutting in areas like cloud hosting will lead to difficulties in maintaining Twitter’s infrastructure, The Verge reports.<\/span><\/div>\n<\/div>\n<p>Advertisers are growing worried about what the significant job cuts in key areas mean for brand safety and began putting their campaigns on pause until they know how this all shakes out. Twitter\u2019s chief customer officer, Sarah Personette, who managed the company\u2019s relationships with advertisers, also departed last Friday as a result of the takeover. Musk, of course, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/04\/musk-blames-activist-groups-for-major-advertisers-pausing-spending-on-twitter\/\">blames “activist groups” pressure<\/a> for the advertiser situation and not his own actions.<\/p>\n<p>The Twitter product is also rapidly undergoing a change, as Musk plans to cut new features <a href=\"https:\/\/www.platformer.news\/p\/inside-twitters-product-roadmap-under?post_id=82372028\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">like Revue and Notes<\/a>, and revamp the Twitter Blue subscription to make the blue check now a paid feature. He’s also been <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/31\/elon-musk-vine-reboot-poll\/\">thinking about rebooting Vine<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>To say the changes are coming at a chaotic pace is an understatement. Employees were let go via emails and often still working when suddenly their access to Twitter’s internal resources was cut. (Not being able to log in was a clue to go check their personal email to find out if their job was eliminated.)<\/p>\n<p>Musk never communicated with staff before the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/04\/twitter-faces-a-class-action-lawsuit-over-mass-employee-layoffs-with-proper-legal-notice\/\">layoffs<\/a>, reports said. But his message, nonetheless was clear: Twitter is being reformed and it’s not going to be the same place it was ever again. The question now is, will users stay for it?<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"UwxAX25ZAT\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/04\/twitter-faces-a-class-action-lawsuit-over-mass-employee-layoffs-with-proper-legal-notice\/\">Twitter sued in class action lawsuit over mass layoffs without proper legal notice<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Twitter sued in class action lawsuit over mass layoffs without proper legal notice” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/04\/twitter-faces-a-class-action-lawsuit-over-mass-employee-layoffs-with-proper-legal-notice\/embed\/#?secret=PrwzEM0PvX#?secret=UwxAX25ZAT\" data-secret=\"UwxAX25ZAT\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<h3>Mastodon benefits from the Twitter exodus<\/h3>\n<p>As it turns out, some people decided they won’t be sticking around for whatever Twitter is turning into.<\/p>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\">The open source, decentralized social network <a href=\"https:\/\/joinmastodon.org\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Mastodon<\/a> is one platform that has benefitted from the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/elon-buys-twitter\/\">Twitter takeover<\/a>. In addition to seeing <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/31\/mastodons-microblogging-app-saw-a-record-number-of-downloads-after-musks-twitter-takeover\/\">a record number of downloads<\/a>\u00a0for the Mastodon mobile app this past weekend, the\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/joinmastodon.org\/about\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">nonprofit<\/a> company <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/03\/decentralized-social-network-mastodon-grows-to-655k-users-in-wake-of-elon-musks-twitter-takeover\/\">also this week announced<\/a> a new milestone. In a post on Twitter \u2014 where Mastodon has been successfully marketing its app to those now considering leaving the service \u2014 it noted that 230,000 people have joined Mastodon during the last week alone. Thanks to these new sign-ups, as well as people returning to old accounts they had set up previously, the network now has 655,000 active users, the post said.<\/p>\n<p>This is the highest number of users Mastodon has seen to date and follows on news that the network\u00a0had gained <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/joinmastodon\/status\/1586525904997863427\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">over 70,000 new sign-ups<\/a> on Friday, October 28 \u2014 the day after Musk\u2019s deal to acquire Twitter had closed. From Friday through Sunday, the Mastodon mobile app also <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/31\/mastodons-microblogging-app-saw-a-record-number-of-downloads-after-musks-twitter-takeover\/\">saw around 91,000 new installs<\/a>, third-party data from Sensor Tower indicated \u2014 a 658% increase from the 12,000 installs it saw the three days prior.<\/p>\n<p>This rapid growth had some downsides as the largest service mastodon.social experienced lags and outages due to the sudden influx of new users. Plus, some users came to Mastodon without a full understanding of how a decentralized social network works and have found the process confusing or overly technical. They may have already given up and moved on to another platform, despite how this week was the prime opportunity to convince them of decentralization’s perks — like how Mastodon can’t be sold to a person like Musk.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"lzymosU6I2\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/03\/decentralized-social-network-mastodon-grows-to-655k-users-in-wake-of-elon-musks-twitter-takeover\/\">Decentralized social network Mastodon grows to 655K users in wake of Elon Musk’s Twitter takeover<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Decentralized social network Mastodon grows to 655K users in wake of Elon Musk’s Twitter takeover” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/03\/decentralized-social-network-mastodon-grows-to-655k-users-in-wake-of-elon-musks-twitter-takeover\/embed\/#?secret=4VG6T37hre#?secret=lzymosU6I2\" data-secret=\"lzymosU6I2\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>Soon, another decentralized social app will come for Twitter’s user base. Twitter co-founder and former CEO Jack Dorsey is launching <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/08\/16\/twitter-taps-crypto-developer-to-lead-bluesky-decentralized-social-network-effort\/\">Bluesky<\/a>, a decentralized social protocol and <a href=\"https:\/\/bsky.app\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">app<\/a> that intends to build a Twitter-like product in a different way. But the open source community <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theverge.com\/2019\/12\/12\/21012553\/twitter-bluesky-decentralized-social-network-developers-reaction-mastodon-activitypub\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">has been frustrated<\/a>\u00a0with the Silicon Valley exec\u2019s decision to go his own way with Bluesky, instead of using established protocols like ActivityPub,\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/MastodonProject\/status\/1204774808015327232\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">which powers Mastodon<\/a> and others.<\/p>\n<p>Then there’s the fact that @Jack sold Twitter to Musk to begin with, so would anyone ever trust him again?<\/p>\n<h3>Substack takes aim at Twitter, too<\/h3>\n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">Another company hoping to capitalize on Twitter\u2019s upheaval is the newsletter platform Substack. The company openly targeted Twitter\u2019s user base over the past few days and then threw its hat into the ring as a more direct competitor with the launch of a new feature, Substack Chat. This addition allows Substack writers to communicate directly with their most avid and loyal readers right in the Substack mobile app.<\/span><\/p>\n<div>\n<p>With Chat, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/03\/substack-targets-twitter-with-launch-of-discussions-feature-substack-chat\/\">Substack is not only taking on Twitter<\/a>, where many back-and-forth threaded discussions between writers and readers already take place, but also other online communities where writers have been building out networks of their own, like Discord, Slack and Telegram.<\/p>\n<p>The company says the new Chat feature will eliminate the need for its writers to \u201cfrankenstein together different software tools and cross-reference subscriber lists,\u201d its announcement read.<\/p>\n<p>Chat is not a Twitter clone by any means \u2014 though there is overlap with how writers have used Twitter in the past.<\/p>\n<p>For starters, the Chat feature will be opt-in, meaning not every newsletter may have chats enabled at this time.\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/support.substack.com\/hc\/en-us\/articles\/10409888763668\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Publications will have to first enable the feature<\/a> on their Settings page or by simply starting a new thread in the Substack app. The user interface is also not a timeline to scroll, but resembles a traditional chat app.<\/p>\n<p>However, the launch could relocate some of the discussions that would have normally taken place on Twitter to a more private networking space going forward.<\/p>\n<\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"VatS56G28s\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/03\/substack-targets-twitter-with-launch-of-discussions-feature-substack-chat\/\">Substack targets Twitter with launch of discussions feature, Substack The app is not yet available to the public.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Cross-platform app Darkroom <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/03\/darkroom-brings-high-end-photo-smarts-to-your-icloud-photo-library\/\">got a major update<\/a> <\/strong>that includes highlight and shadow recovery to allow users to make the most of the ProRAW files captured by the latest-generation iPhones. It also added Preset Sharing and new sliders for\u00a0Exposure, Whites, Highlights, Shadows and Blacks.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h3>Messaging<\/h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Telegram <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theverge.com\/2022\/10\/30\/23430234\/telegram-pulls-paywalled-posts-ios-apple-app-store-rules-bots\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">removed a feature<\/a> that let iOS users create pay-to-view posts,<\/strong> which creators were selling access to through third-party payments or donation bots, citing Apple’s App Store Rules. Apple’s policies don’t allow for third-party payment processors and require developers to pay up to a 30% commission on in-app purchases.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h3>Dating<\/h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Match Group <a href=\"https:\/\/www.marketwatch.com\/story\/tinder-owner-match-group-tops-estimates-for-revenue-stock-jumps-over-10-11667335891?mod=mw_latestnews\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">beat on earnings<\/a> with Q3 revenue up 1% YoY to $810 million, above the $793 million estimated.<\/strong> Paying users were up 2% YoY to 16.5 million, and the stock climbed 15+% on the news. The company said in 2023 it would invest in Hinge, The League and two new apps targeting specific demographics.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h3>Streaming & Entertainment<\/h3>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2434541\" style=\"width: 1330px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2434541\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2434541 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/11\/amazon-music.webp\" alt=\"\" width=\"1320\" height=\"743\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/11\/amazon-music.webp 1320w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/11\/amazon-music.webp?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/11\/amazon-music.webp?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/11\/amazon-music.webp?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/11\/amazon-music.webp?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/11\/amazon-music.webp?resize=1200,675 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/11\/amazon-music.webp?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1320px) 100vw, 1320px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2434541\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Amazon<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Amazon <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/01\/amazon-prime-now-comes-with-a-full-music-catalog-of-100-million-songs-and-ad-free-podcasts\/\">rolled out a new benefit<\/a> for its Prime members with the addition of a full music catalog with 100 million songs,<\/strong> instead of the previously more limited selection of just 2 million songs. It will also make most of the top podcasts on its service available without ads, and added a \u201cPodcast Previews\u201d feature to its Music app that allows customers to listen to short clips as a way to discover new podcasts they may like. Users can still upgrade to on-demand music as before with Amazon Music Unlimited.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Disney+ expanded into e-commerce.<\/strong>\u00a0The streaming service <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/01\/disney-expands-into-e-commerce-with-an-exclusive-merch-shop-for-subscribers\/\">introduced a new subscriber perk<\/a> that offers early access to select merchandise associated with brands like Star Wars, Marvel, Disney Animation Studios and Pixar. Subscribers will see the merch listed on the detail pages of select movies, shorts and TV shows on the service. They can then hold up their phone to scan a QR code to buy the items or they can visit the <a href=\"http:\/\/shopDisney.com\/DisneyPlusSpecialAccess\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">website<\/a> directly and authenticate with their Disney+ credentials.<\/li>\n<li><strong>YouTube rolled out Primetime Channels in the U.S.<\/strong> The video platform <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/01\/youtube-sells-streaming-subscriptions-with-primetime-channels\/\">partnered with 35 streamers<\/a>, including Paramount+, Showtime, Epix, Starz, AMC+ and others, which can be found in the Movies & Shows hub.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Clubhouse<a href=\"https:\/\/blog.clubhouse.com\/introducing-background-music-and-sound-reactions\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> added support<\/a> for background music and sound reactions<\/strong> to its audio streaming platform.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Newly added references <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/04\/bytedances-music-app-resso-offers-hints-about-tiktok-musics-launch\/\">to a “TikTok Music” service have appeared<\/a> in the code of the Resso streaming app,<\/strong> owned by TikTok\u2019s parent ByteDance. The code appears to suggest that user activity may sync between the Resso app and TikTok Music, and specifically refers to a \u201cmusic.tiktok.com\u201d URL. The company has also set up social accounts for TikTok Music, signaling a possible Resso rebrand and expansion.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h3>Gaming<\/h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Google <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/03\/google-play-games-for-pc-program-expands-to-the-us-and-seven-other-countries\/\">expanded<\/a> its Google Play Games beta for PC to the U.S.,<\/strong> and seven other countries, including Canada, Mexico, Brazil, Indonesia, the Phillippines, Malaysia and Singapore. The service offers 85 Android games that can be played on Windows PCs. Over the last couple of months Google added popular titles like \u201c1945 Air Force,\u201d \u201cBlade Idle,\u201d \u201cCookie Run: Kingdom\u201d and \u201cEvony: The King\u2019s Return\u201d among others.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h3>Travel & Transportation<\/h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Uber <a href=\"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2022-11-01\/uber-beats-sales-estimates-on-strong-ridership-driver-supply\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">beat in Q3<\/a> with revenue up 72% YoY to $8.34 billion,<\/strong>\u00a0above estimates of $8.1 billion. Gross bookings were up 26% YoY to $29.1 billion, which included $13.7 billion from Uber Eats.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Uber also began annoying its users with unsolicited push notification ads this week.<\/strong> Beginning last weekend,<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/31\/uber-tests-push-notifications-a-feature-literally-no-one-wants\/\"> people began complaining about the notification<\/a>-based<a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/matsonj\/status\/1586857522950209536\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">\u00a0ads<\/a>, which included those for non-Uber businesses, like Peloton. Users said the notifications were being sent out when they weren’t even engaging with the Uber app itself. Uber claimed it was a limited test and noted people could turn off the notifications in the app if they didn’t like the ads.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h3>Utilities<\/h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Google <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/02\/google-assistant-gains-new-parental-controls-kid-friendly-answers-and-voices\/\">announced new parental controls<\/a> for its Google Assistant platform.<\/strong> The new features will roll out over the next several weeks to Google Home, as well as the Family Link and Google Assistant apps on iOS and Android, and will allow parents to limit or even entirely disable certain Assistant functionality, like calls, configure kid-friendly settings, adjust downtime and more. The settings will also let parents configure default services, limit what sort of answers they can get from the Assistant, and introduce new kid-friendly new voices.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Google <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theverge.com\/2022\/11\/1\/23435733\/google-maps-street-view-standalone-app-discontinue-support\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">will shut down its Street View app<\/a> for iOS and Android in 2023.<\/strong> The app had allowed users to contribute their own 360-degree imagery to Street View.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h3>Government & Policy<\/h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>The U.S Federal Trade Commission <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/01\/ftc-chegg-breaches-cybersecurity\/\">filed a complaint against homework helper app Chegg<\/a> <\/strong>for its security lapses that saw the personal information and password of around 40 million users stolen in 2018. The FTC’s order requires Chegg to strengthen security safeguards, offer consumers an easy way to delete their data and limit information collection on the front end. Chegg said it would comply.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Google indefinitely <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/31\/google-pauses-enforcement-play-store-billing-requirement-in-india-following-antitrust-order\/\">paused enforcement<\/a> of its Google Play Store’s billing policy in India<\/strong> following an order by the country\u2019s antitrust body that ordered the company to stop restricting developers from using third-party payment processing services for in-app purchases and buying apps. The Competition Commission of India also fined Google $113 million for abusing the dominant position of its Play Store in the country.<\/li>\n<li><strong>TikTok <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/03\/tiktok-privacy-policy-update-china\/\">will update its privacy policy<\/a> on December 2 to allow staff outside of Europe, including staff in China, permission to access data belonging to EU users.<\/strong> The change was announced months ahead of a drafted decision into a year-long investigation into the platform’s data exports to china under the GDPR.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h3>Security & Privacy<\/h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Malwarebytes reported four apps listed by the developer Mobile apps Group <a href=\"https:\/\/gizmodo.com\/google-play-phishing-malicious-apps-1849731818\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">contained known malware<\/a><\/strong> that’s used to steal users\u2019 information. The apps were listed on the Play Store as of the time of the reporting on Tuesday.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h1>Funding and M&A<\/h1>\n<p><strong>\ud83e\udd1d Google acquired AI avatar startup Alter for <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/27\/google-acquires-twitter-backed-ai-avatar-startup-alter-for-100-million-source-says\/\">around $100 million<\/a>.<\/strong> The company helped creators and brands express their virtual identities. Does Google have Memoji ambitions? Alter began its life as Facemoji, a platform offering tech that allowed game and app developers to put avatar systems into their apps.<\/p>\n<p><strong>\ud83e\udd1d Netflix <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/31\/netflix-acquires-seattle-based-cozy-games-developer-spry-fox\/\">acquired<\/a> the Seattle-based game developer Spry Fox for an undisclosed sum<\/strong> as part of its mobile gaming push. This is now the company’s sixth in-house studio, after earlier acquisitions, which have included Next Games, Night School Studio and Boss Fight Entertainment. The game developer, founded in 2010, is known for popular titles like \u201cTriple Town,\u201d \u201cAlphabear\u201d and \u201cCozy Grove.\u201d<\/p>\n<p><strong>\ud83d\udcb0 Digital gifting app Givingli <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/01\/digital-card-and-gifting-platform-givingli-nabs-10m\/\">raised $10 million<\/a> in Series A funding<\/strong> led by Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian’s VC firm, Seven Seven Six. The app offers e-cards and e-gifts than can be shared on email, text and social media, and is also integrated with Snapchat as of 2020.<\/p>\n<p> <\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/this-week-in-apps\/\"><img decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-1952542\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"93\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png 2047w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png?resize=150,21 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png?resize=300,41 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png?resize=768,105 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png?resize=680,93 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png?resize=1536,210 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png?resize=1200,164 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png?resize=50,7 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><\/a><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Welcome back to This Week in Apps, the weekly TechCrunch series that recaps the latest in mobile OS news, mobile applications and the overall app economy. Musk just axed key Twitter teams like human rights, accessibility, AI ethics and curation"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Elon Musk is wasting no time making <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/03\/twitter-layoffs-elon-musk\/\">extremely deep cuts<\/a> at Twitter, calving off many teams doing essential work at the company in the process. News of layoffs swept the platform on Friday, showing that Twitter’s billionaire owner is painting in broad strokes when it comes to trimming down the team by half.<\/p>\n<p>The same day that Musk complained about supposed activists impacting Twitter’s ad revenue, he cut some departments outright \u2014 actions that are sure to make advertisers all the more skittish about Musk’s ability to steer a ship with a skeleton crew. As he’s only owned the company for a single week, it’s impossible to imagine that such sweeping layoffs won’t lead to dysfunction at Twitter, from the content moderation policies sure to prove crucial for Tuesday’s U.S. midterm elections to product teams keeping the platform humming.<\/p>\n<p>Former Twitter employees affected by the layoffs describe a chaotic situation with little official communication beyond abruptly receiving a termination letter or seeing their access to internal tools like Slack or databases suddenly revoked. In the information vacuum created by Musk’s disorganized and sudden approach to the layoffs, some employees aren’t sure if their colleagues are still employed or if their teams continue to exist at all.<\/p>\n<p>The cuts appear to be as broad as they were deep, affecting everything from Twitter’s trust and safety teams that handle content moderation to its marketing department. Here are some of the teams either eliminated outright or hit hard by the layoffs, and what the new incarnation of Twitter will be losing in the process.<\/p>\n<h3>Human Rights<\/h3>\n<p>Former Twitter Human Rights Counsel Shannon Raj Singh shared news that the company’s human rights team was eliminated Friday. The team worked to protect users facing human rights violations around the globe, including activists, journalists and people affected by conflicts like the war in Ukraine.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Yesterday was my last day at Twitter: the entire Human Rights team has been cut from the company.<\/p>\n<p>I am enormously proud of the work we did to implement the UN Guiding Principles on Business & Human Rights, to protect those at-risk in global conflicts & crises including Ethiopia,<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>— Shannon Raj Singh (@ShannonRSingh) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/ShannonRSingh\/status\/1588591603622772736?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 4, 2022<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<h3>Accessibility Experience<\/h3>\n<p>Twitter’s now former head of accessibility confirmed that the company cut the accessibility experience team, which improved the product for people with disabilities. The team appears to have had a lot still in the works before it was disbanded.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">So, the Accessibility Experience Team at Twitter is no longer. We had so much more to do, but we worked hard! There aren't very many people that have had the opportunity to make such an important global platform like Twitter accessible, but we understood the mission.<\/p>\n<p>— Gerard K. Cohen (@gerardkcohen) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/gerardkcohen\/status\/1588584479072714752?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 4, 2022<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">November <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/hashtag\/TwitterA11yStatus?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#TwitterA11yStatus<\/a><br \/>Launched:<br \/>– Image description reminder<br \/>In progress:<br \/>– ALT badge copy\/paste for mobile<br \/>– Improved image description education<br \/>Next:<br \/>– Setting to disable keyboard shortcuts on Web<br \/>Exploring:<br \/>– Closed captions toggle<br \/>– Anniversary images missing alt text<\/p>\n<p>— Twitter Accessibility (@TwitterA11y) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/TwitterA11y\/status\/1587533210354946049?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 1, 2022<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<h3>Communications<\/h3>\n<p>It’s not yet clear what parts of Twitter’s communications team have been cut outright, but the cuts are deep enough that many prominent comms employees at the company, including many contacts that TechCrunch has spoken with over the years, were affected. Musk signaled his distaste for internal communications immediately after taking over the company, conveying little information to Twitter employees about the changes, so it’s no surprise that the internal communications team is affected as well, including the head of internal comms.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Twitter is so special. After 4 yrs, I\u2019m leaving with the fullest \ud83d\udc99, experiences I never imagined, and unbreakable bonds with so many Tweeps. My head is held high, knowing I gave it my absolute all. <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/TwitterComms?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@TwitterComms<\/a>: We have so much to be proud of. Time to fly even higher! <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/hashtag\/OneTeam?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#OneTeam<\/a> <a href=\"https:\/\/t.co\/5tVUP575A6\">pic.twitter.com\/5tVUP575A6<\/a><\/p>\n<p>— Julie Steele (@juliezsteele) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/juliezsteele\/status\/1588419360388833280?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 4, 2022<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Many don\u2019t know all the details that went into internal comms this year, but I do. I also know that the people at Twitter embody <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/hashtag\/OneTeam?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#OneTeam<\/a> . No one goes harder than <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/TwitterComms?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@TwitterComms<\/a>. Ultimately, I get to leave with the best people alongside me. Cheers<\/p>\n<p>— Colette Zakarian (@colzakarian) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/colzakarian\/status\/1588400692594499584?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 4, 2022<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<h3>Machine learning ethics, transparency and accountability<\/h3>\n<p>Musk dissolved a team known internally as META, which was well-respected for its exploratory work in ethical AI and algorithmic transparency. Rumman Chowdhury, the team’s director, was <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/ruchowdh\/status\/1588374979061874691\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">eliminated<\/a>, along with the team’s engineers and other members.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">\ud83e\udee1 Yep, the team is gone. The team that was researching and pushing for algorithmic transparency and algorithmic choice. The team that was studying algorithmic amplification. The team that was inventing and building ethical AI tooling and methodologies. All that is gone.<\/p>\n<p>— Joan Deitchman (@JoanDeitchman) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/JoanDeitchman\/status\/1588430085035474944?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 4, 2022<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<h3>Curation<\/h3>\n<p>Some of the layoffs make sense, given the things Musk apparently has little regard for (human rights and accessibility, alarming!), but Twitter’s new owner apparently also made cuts to teams that seemed poised to help him extract more value from the company. The <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/i\/en\/curation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">curation team<\/a> curated the moments tab, programmed the trending topics section, provided context on those topics and also handled live events \u2014 many of the things Twitter does best. The team also worked to fight misinformation on the platform \u2014 a serious and consequential concerns that Musk has <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/31\/elon-musk-twitter-lgbt-community\/\">already made worse<\/a> in less than seven days on the job.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">So Twitter\u2019s Curation team is no more.<\/p>\n<p>This site \ud83d\udc47 was recently launched to tell the world about our work. Give it a look for two reasons:<\/p>\n<p>1) to see how it will impact your experience <br \/>2) if you want to hire the people behind it, get in touch via DM<a href=\"https:\/\/t.co\/vGdlDSYh8r\">https:\/\/t.co\/vGdlDSYh8r<\/a><\/p>\n<p>— Andrew Haigh (@AndrewHaigh) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/AndrewHaigh\/status\/1588468986596859904?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 4, 2022<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Looks like Elon Musk fired the entire curation team. <\/p>\n<p>These were the folks who tackled misinfo, contextualized conversations via the 'Explore' page, and  helped make Twitter an unmatched source for breaking news.<\/p>\n<p>This will make Twitter noisier, more dangerous & less interesting<\/p>\n<p>— Richie Assaly (@rdassaly) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/rdassaly\/status\/1588526469059223552?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 4, 2022<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<h3>Public policy<\/h3>\n<p>Politico <a href=\"https:\/\/www.politico.com\/news\/2022\/11\/04\/elon-musk-twitter-chaos-midterms-00065192\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reports<\/a> that half of the company’s public policy team was let go, including Michele Austin, the former director of public policy and elections in Canada and the U.S. who was actively working on the U.S. midterms. Those cuts reportedly also included Twitter team members who work to verify the accounts of political figures.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">I helped lead the 2022 US midterms on platform. Same with <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/hashtag\/Elxn44?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#Elxn44<\/a> in Canada. I was responsible for social impact work in both countries. Twitter gave me amazing opportunities.<\/p>\n<p>— Michele Austin (@_MicheleAustin) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/_MicheleAustin\/status\/1588501100151603202?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 4, 2022<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<p><em>This story is developing…<\/em><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Elon Musk is wasting no time making extremely deep cuts at Twitter, calving off many teams doing essential work at the company in the process. Budibase, a low-code open-source web app builder with automations"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">While there are <a href=\"https:\/\/www.gartner.com\/en\/newsroom\/press-releases\/2021-06-10-gartner-says-the-majority-of-technology-products-and-services-will-be-built-by-professionals-outside-of-it-by-2024\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">differing perspectives<\/a> on the degree to which no-code and low-code development tools could eventually supplant human software developers, it’s clear that any software that takes care of the technical “heavy lifting” is <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/10\/6-technologists-discuss-how-no-code-tools-are-changing-software-development\/\">having a huge impact within businesses<\/a> — in terms of opening app-building to more personnel, plugging the talent gap and helping existing developers focus on more demanding tasks.<\/p>\n<p>A quick peek across the recent funding landscape shows little sign of the no-code \/ low-code movement slowing. In 2022 alone we’ve seen the likes of <a href=\"https:\/\/www.prnewswire.com\/news-releases\/webflow-raises-120m-series-c-at-4b-valuation-led-by-yc-continuity-301503860.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Webflow draw in $120 million<\/a> for a no-code website builder; <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/01\/19\/softrs-series-a-is-a-reminder-that-the-no-code-boom-continues\/\">Softr raise a $13.5 million Series A<\/a> to help companies build apps on top of Airtable databases; <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/06\/22\/appsmith-takes-open-source-route-to-accelerate-internal-business-app-development\/\">Appsmith secure a $41 million Series B<\/a> to power customized internal business apps; <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/07\/28\/retool-raises-45m-at-a-3-2b-valuation-to-make-building-custom-software-as-easy-as-buying-off-the-shelf\/\">Retool attract a $45 million cash injection<\/a> for a similar proposition; and <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/04\/05\/thunkable-raises-30m-after-its-no-code-mobile-app-development-platform-hits-3m-users-and-6m-apps\/\">Thunkable lock down a $30 million<\/a> investment for a no-code mobile app development platform.<\/p>\n<p>So despite the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/09\/27\/what-can-the-2000-dotcom-crash-teach-us-about-the-2022-tech-downturn\/\">broader downturn<\/a>, it seems that 2022 may have been relatively kind to startups operating in the no- and low-code sphere, something that fledgling Northern Irish startup <a href=\"https:\/\/budibase.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Budibase<\/a> is capitalizing on with the announcement of a fresh $7 million tranche of funding to further develop an open source web app builder.<\/p>\n<p>Founded out of Belfast in 2019, Budibase allows users to connect to an external data source — such as Postgres, MySQL, Oracle, Google Sheets or Airtable — and develop internal tools or business apps in minutes. Such apps may include anything from customer helpdesk applications, application tracking systems and inventory management systems, to admin panels, portals and forms.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2436939\" style=\"width: 717px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2436939\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2436939\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/11\/ezgif.com-gif-maker4.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"707\" height=\"534\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2436939\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Example business application in action. <strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Budibase<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>It’s also worth noting that Budibase also packs its own built-in database based on CouchDB, for those looking to build apps entirely from scratch.<\/p>\n<p>“Every enterprise we speak with says the same thing — ‘we have a long backlog of internal tool tickets that are holding us back’,” Budibase co-founder Joe Johnston told TechCrunch. “With Budibase, enterprises are building internal tools and transforming workflows in days, not months, which is a huge cost-saving and catalyst for innovation.”<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<h2>Open sourced<\/h2>\n<p>One of Budibase’s core selling points is that it’s open source, which gives companies more flexibility and extensibility, but also allows them to host everything themselves — this is particularly important for enterprises with sensitive data they may wish to protect from the SaaS-y clutches of third-party infrastructure.<\/p>\n<p>In addition to the free self-hosted version of Budibase, the company <a href=\"https:\/\/budibase.com\/pricing\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">also offers<\/a> a range of premium and enterprise plans with add-on features (such as SLAs and unlimited automation logs) and a fully managed hosted incarnation.<\/p>\n<p>Budibase is somewhat similar to other players in the open source low-code development space, including the aforementioned Appsmith and <a href=\"https:\/\/www.joget.org\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Joget<\/a> which, as it happens, announced its first institutional funding earlier this year via a <a href=\"https:\/\/www.prnewswire.com\/news-releases\/no-codelow-code-software-provider-joget-raises-2-2-million-pre-series-a-funding-301459856.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">$2.2 million pre-Series A investment<\/a>. So this highlights the demand not only for no- and low-code app builders, but also the ability to retain full control over company data and gain full insights into what’s going on under the hood.<\/p>\n<p>“Enterprises like this because they have access to the codebase, and they can patch it if they need to [which is useful for] risk mitigation,” Johnston said.<\/p>\n<h2>Automation for the people<\/h2>\n<p>Budibase is looking to set itself apart in a number of ways, through more subjective elements such as usability, but also through specific differentiators such as built-in automations comparable to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2017\/10\/31\/zapier-makes-it-easier-for-teams-to-collaborate-on-their-app-workflows\/\">something like Zapier<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>Indeed, Budibase includes automations that are powered by webhooks and actions that are good to go out-the-box, but which can also be customized by the more technically-minded that want to throw their own scripts into the pot. Such automations can cover any number of use cases, such as automatically approving (or denying) an employee’s leave request through an internal form, or issuing a new inbound lead notification to the sales team at the start of their shift.<\/p>\n<p>“We want to deliver a platform that helps developers and non-developers — but technical employees — innovate and accelerate their workplace,” Johnston said.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2434448\" style=\"width: 949px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2434448\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2434448\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/10\/automation.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"939\" height=\"432\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2434448\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Budibase automation in action. <strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Budibase<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>A quick peek at Budibase’s homepage reveals a fairly impressive roster of company logos, from Google and Netflix to Tesla and Disney. At first glance, it would appear that these are fully signed-up Budibase customers, but alas this is not the case — Budibase <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/03\/scarf-helps-open-source-developers-track-how-their-projects-are-being-used\/\">uses a tracking tool called Scarf<\/a> to detect which domains are downloading the open source Budibase software. So this doesn’t really tell us all that much about <em>how<\/em> Budibase is being used at these companies, whether it’s being tested internally or whether it’s simply curious employees downloading it for their own interests.<\/p>\n<p>“Employees from some of the companies mentioned are active in our community,” Johnston said. “For example, Scarf told us Google has pulled down the Budibase Docker image over 150 times.”<\/p>\n<p>Budibase had raised $1.8 million in seed funding prior to now, and its latest $7 million “seed II” funding round included investments from SignalFire, Angular Ventures, Techstart and a slew of angel backers.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>While there are differing perspectives on the degree to which no-code and low-code development tools could fintech layoffs just keep on coming"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><em>Welcome to\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/the-interchange\/\">The Interchange<\/a>! If you received this in your inbox, thank you for signing up and your vote of confidence. If you\u2019re reading this as a post on our site, sign up\u00a0<\/em><a href=\"http:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\"><em>here<\/em><\/a><em>\u00a0so you can receive it directly in the future. Every week, I\u2019ll take a look at the hottest fintech news of the previous week. This will include everything from funding rounds to trends to an analysis of a particular space to hot takes on a particular company or phenomenon. There\u2019s a lot of fintech news out there and it\u2019s my job to stay on top of it \u2014 and make sense of it \u2014 so you can stay in the know. \u2014\u00a0<\/em><a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bayareawriter\"><em>Mary Ann<\/em><\/a><\/p>\n<p>Wow, I take off one week and come back to all hell breaking loose in the fintech world.<\/p>\n<p>Sadly, it felt like we got news of layoff after layoff.<\/p>\n<p>I\u2019ll attempt to round up as many of them as I can here:<\/p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/02\/digital-bank-chime-is-cutting-costs-across-the-board-including-12-of-staff\/\">Chime confirmed that it is letting go of 12% of its employees.<\/a>\u00a0<\/strong>This equals about 160 people. According to an internal memo obtained by TechCrunch, Chime co-founder Chris Britt said that the move was one of many that would help the company thrive \u201cregardless of market conditions.\u201d In the memo, Britt said that he and co-founder Ryan King are recalibrating marketing spend, decreasing the number of contractors, adjusting workspace needs and renegotiating vendor contractors.<\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/02\/opendoor-lays-off-about-550-employees-or-18-of-its-workforce\/\"><strong>Opendoor announced it was letting go of 18% of its staff. <\/strong><\/a>This is around 500 people. Opendoor co-founder and CEO Eric Wu said his company, a publicly traded real estate fintech, was navigating \u201cone of the most challenging real estate markets in 40 years.\u201d<\/li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/02\/tiger-global-chargebee-layoffs\/\">Chargebee has laid off about 10% of its staff.<\/a>\u00a0<\/strong>As reported by <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/jagmeets13\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Jagmeet<\/a>\u00a0on November 2, \u201cChargebee, backed by marquee investors including Tiger Global and Sequoia Capital India, has laid off about 10% of its staff in a ‘reorganization’ effort due to ongoing global macroeconomic challenges and growing operational debt. The Chennai and San Francisco\u2013headquartered startup, which offers billing, subscription, revenue and compliance management solutions, confirmed to TechCrunch that the update impacted 142 employees.\u201d<\/li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/03\/stripe-cuts-14-of-its-workforce-ceo-says-they-overhired-for-the-world-were-in\/\">Stripe lays off 14% of its staff.<\/a> <\/strong>As reported by <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/psawers\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Paul<\/a>, \u201cStripe has announced that it\u2019s laying off 14% of its workers, impacting around 1,120 of the fintech giant\u2019s 8,000 workforce.” In a memo published online, Stripe CEO Patrick Collison conveyed a familiar narrative in terms of the reasons behind the latest cutbacks: a major hiring spree spurred by the world\u2019s pandemic-driven surge toward e-commerce, a significant growth period and then an economic downturn ridden with inflation, higher interest rates and other macroeconomic challenges.<\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/04\/spend-management-startup-pleo-lays-off-15-of-its-workforce\/\"><strong>Danish startup Pleo may lay off 15% of its workers. <\/strong><\/a>Jeppe Rindom, co-founder and CEO of Pleo \u2014\u00a0which less than one year ago <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/12\/08\/pleo-picks-up-200m-at-a-4-7b-valuation-to-build-the-next-generation-of-business-expense-management\/\">raised $200 million at a $4.7 billion valuation<\/a> \u2014 revealed that the company\u2019s new strategy will <a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/posts\/jepperindom_dear-friends-at-pleo-we-frequently-share-activity-6993942386196283393-ZrB8\/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">impact 15% of its roles<\/a>. He added that \u201cup to 150 of our colleagues may have to leave.\u201d Pleo is a developer of expense management tools aimed at SMBs to let them issue company cards and better manage how employees spend money.<\/li>\n<li><span class=\"gradient-text gradient-text--green-gradient\"><strong>Credit Karma, now a subsidiary of Intuit, has \u201cdecided to pause almost all hiring.\u201d<\/strong><\/span> This is according to an internal email sent to employees by chief people officer Colleen McCreary. McCreary referenced \u201crevenue challenges due to the uncertain environment.\u201d This was reiterated in <a href=\"https:\/\/www.investors.intuit.com\/news\/news-details\/2022\/Intuit-Reiterates-Operating-Income-and-Earnings-per-Share-Guidance-for-Fiscal-Year-2023-Expects-to-Report-First-Quarter-Results-Above-Guidance\/default.aspx\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Intuit\u2019s fourth quarter earnings call<\/a>, during which the company shared on November 1 that \u201call Credit Karma verticals have been negatively impacted by macro uncertainty. Credit Karma experienced further deterioration in these verticals during the last few weeks of the first quarter.\u201d<\/li>\n<li><span class=\"gradient-text gradient-text--green-gradient\"><strong>Remote online notarization services<\/strong> <strong>provider<\/strong> <strong>Notarize cuts its team by 60 people.<\/strong><\/span> A spokesperson told me via email that \u201cthe reorganization impacted nearly all teams and the decision was in service to the larger strategy we have been enacting at Notarize, and will enable us to move faster to best serve our customers.\u201d The spokesperson added that in September, one small real estate\u2013focused team was laid off in response to both its strategy shift and \u201cthe drastic drop in demand from the specific customers that they served.\u201d The recent layoffs follow <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/06\/16\/notarize-cuts-25-of-staff\/\">a larger layoff in June<\/a> that impacted 110 people. Prior to that reduction, Notarize had about 440 employees. It currently employs 250 people across the United States.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p>I wrote this newsletter on November 3 because I’m leaving on a trip to celebrate my 20th wedding anniversary, so it\u2019s possible that more layoffs took place between then and now. :( What this means for the broader fintech world is not yet clear, but when well-funded companies such as Chime, Stripe and Pleo are cutting staff, it is no doubt sobering for all the players — small or large — in the space.<\/p>\n<p>Special thanks to TC senior reporter and very nice guy <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/kyle_l_wiggers\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Kyle Wiggers<\/a> for helping me draft the Weekly News and Fundings and M&A sections below so I could get offline and pack for my trip!<\/p>\n<h2>Weekly News<\/h2>\n<p><strong>Jeeves<\/strong>, the fintech startup that<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/22\/fintech-startup-jeeves-raises-180m-quadruples-valuation-to-2-1b\/\"> recently<\/a> raised $180 million at a $2.1 billion valuation, told TechCrunch via email that it has launched a service called Jeeves Pay that it’s billing as a “credit-backed business payments solution” for enterprise customers. At a high level, Jeeves Pay lets customers use their existing credit line to send wires or pay vendors, ostensibly solving the problem of having to rely on cash or revenues to fund local and cross-border business and vendor payments. Jeeves Pay is available now to all Jeeves customers “where permitted by applicable local laws and regulations,” the company says.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><strong>Brex<\/strong> sees startups as one of the key avenues to growth in the corporate card and spend management market. To that end, the company on Wednesday <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/02\/brex-techstars-partnership-henrique-dubugras\/\">announced<\/a> a partnership with Techstars to extend Brex services to companies within the accelerator, following similar tie-ups with Y Combinator and AngelList. For the duration of the accelerator, Techstars participants will get a Brex platform support team, access to exclusive Brex events and free use of Brex’s Pry financial forecasting platform. In an interview with TechCrunch, Brex CEO and co-founder Henrique Dubugras described the move as a customer acquisition play.<\/p>\n<p>At Disrupt, TechCrunch interviewed <strong>Brex’s<\/strong> Dubugras onstage about the company’s recent change in strategy, which involves a stronger emphasis on software and the enterprise. A <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/02\/brex-co-founder-henrique-dubugras-details-decisions-behind-pivots-layoffs-going-remote\/\">piece<\/a> for TC+ breaks out the juicy highlights from the conversation, including why Brex decided to stop serving businesses funded outside the venture capital structure and the implications of the company’s layoffs earlier this year.<\/p>\n<p>Also at Disrupt, <strong>Ramp<\/strong> CEO Eric Glyman, Airbase CEO Thejo Kote, and Anthemis partner Ruth Foxe Blader participated in a roundtable about competing in the increasingly crowded spend management space — a space, it’s worth noting, that’s <a href=\"https:\/\/www.globenewswire.com\/news-release\/2022\/10\/17\/2535190\/0\/en\/With-11-1-CAGR-Business-Spend-Management-BSM-Software-Market-Size-Worth-USD-39-05-Billion-In-2029.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">estimated<\/a> to be worth tens of billions of dollars. Glyman and Kote shared how they\u2019re working to preserve capital, while Blader offered up some of the advice she\u2019s giving to her portfolio companies. Our TC+ recap has the<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/03\/investors-advice-during-a-downturn-dont-panic\/\"> highlights<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>How can finance-focused proptech startups survive the downturn? In an exclusive for TC+, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/02\/proptech-in-review-3-investors-explain-how-finance-focused-proptech-startups-can-survive-the-downturn\/\">we asked three seasoned investors to give their perspectives<\/a>. One of the major takeaways: The chances of survival are higher for proptech startups that let consumers fractionally invest in properties and increase access for those seeking a rent-to-own approach. Another: Companies that help others navigate tough times seem to be in special demand.<\/p>\n<p>Are landlords and tenants finally ready to ditch paper checks? <strong>JPMorgan Chase<\/strong> is betting that they are. The bank this week<a href=\"https:\/\/www.cnbc.com\/2022\/10\/31\/jpmorgan-chase-unveils-payments-platform-for-landlords-and-tenants.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> launched<\/a> a pilot platform for property owners and managers that automates the invoicing and receipt of online rent payments. The market is enormous — JPMorgan estimates that more than 100 million Americans pay a combined $500 billion annually in rent to 12 million property owners — but convincing landlords to move from checks and money orders won’t be an easy feat.
